description: A word of unknown origin, first recorded in Scots sources from the late fifteenth century; but probably from Old Norse herpast (“to suffer from cramp”) the middle voice verb. Compare the Icelandic herpa (“to contract, to draw together”).

verbs.description: hirple (third-person singular simple present hirples, present participle hirpling, simple past and past participle hirpled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Scotland, northern UK) To walk with a limp, to drag a limb, to walk lamely; to move with a gait somewhere between walking and crawling.
examples: Get you on that bicycle and hurry on, and I'll hirple after you the best I can.
